acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 24 hours LC50=0.07mmol/L of the crustacea (Brine Shrimp) (AQUIRE, 2003).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the LC50 (4 hours) value of 26,610ppm, calculated from the testing data of mouse LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 86.24 mg/L (6 hours) (ACGIH 7th, 2001) obtained using trans-1,2-dichloroethylene, was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (238,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 180 Torr (20degC) (ACGIH 7th, 2001), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm, although no data were available for 1,2-dichloroethylene (mixture).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 2,080mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 1,275mg/kg (ACGIH 7th, 2001), 7,900mg/kg (ATSDR, 2001) and 10,000mg/kg (ATSDR, 2001) using trans-1,2-dichloroethylene, although no data were available for 1,2-dichloroethylene (mixture).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 2 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (log Kow=2(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(HSDB, 2004)), it was classified into Category 2.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classified into Class 3 (UN#1150) by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods

explosives.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flashing points are 6degC for cis-dichloroethylene and 2-4degC for trans-dichloroethylene (ICSC, 2003) (closed cup flash test); the boiling point is 55degC -- which is classified into Category 2, or Class 3 and Container II (UN#1150, UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of positive data on heritable/germ-cell in vivo mutagenicity tests and the presence of negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, described in NTP TOX55 (2002).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine (but not oxygen and fluorine), with the chlorine bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the flashing point is 460degC (ICSC,2003)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: No data available, though containing unsaturated bonds. Classified into Class 3 (UN#1150) by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from the rabbit eye irritation test using trans-1,2-dichloroethylene (CERI Hazard Data 2000-46, 2001), although no data were available for 1,2-dichloroethylene (mixture).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from the rabbit skin irritation test using trans-1,2-dichloroethylene (CERI Hazard Data 2000-46, 2001), although no data were available for 1,2-dichloroethylene (mixture).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "marked decreases in complete blood counts, red blood cell counts, hemoglobin levels and hematocrit values" (ATSDR, 1996). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "nausea, vomiting, tremor, oppressing feeling in the upper abdomen and depression of the central nervous system" (CERI Hazard Assessment 2000-46, 2001) and the evidence from animal studies including "a 45% loss of swimming capability" (ATSDR, 1996). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
